 I. ECONOMIC SETTING A. Background 1.1 The Organization of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS), comprises Antigua and Barbuda, the Commonwealth of Dominica, Grenada, St. Kitts and Nevis, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and Montserrat, which is not a member of the World Bank. The OECS was formed in 1968 as a common market which falls within the Caribbean Community (CARICOM) - a larger 12-country regional organization. The OECS countries share a common currency, the Eastern Caribbean dollar (EC$) and a central bank. The EC dollar has been pegged to the US dollar at an exchange rate of EC$2.70 to one US dollar since 1976. 1.2 The climate of each of the countries is tropical with average temperatures ranging from 23 degree C in winter to 32 degree C in summer, and cooler temperatures at higher elevations. Some of the countries experience a rainy season extending from May to November. The geography of the countries is somewhat similar; Antigua and Barbuda, and St. Kitts are relatively flat with sandy soil overlying bedrock; the countries of Dominica, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines and Nevis are mostly rugged and of volcanic in origin with fertile soil and extensive forest coverage; and Grenada, which is comprised of a main island with a number of smaller islands and islets, has a combination of flat plains, mountainous interiors and dense forests. The combined total land area of these countries is less than 3,000 sq. km. 1.3 All of the countries are small, with fragile ecosystems and relatively low overall population densities as a result of the mountainous nature of much of the countries. In 1991 the total combined population of the countries was enumerated at just over 500,000, approximately half of which (the exception being St. Vincent and the Grenadines) live in urban settlements. 1993 GNP per capita ranges from US$2,130 in St.Vincent and the Grenadines to US$6,390 in Antigua and Barbuda (Table 1.1). 1.4 Development in the OECS countries has taken place on a limited and fragile economic base. In addition to being prone to repeated natural disasters (hurricanes), their highly open economies make them vulnerable to external vicissitudes, with a large share of their exports, which is of agricultural origin (bananas and sugar), dependent on preferential market arrangements. Overall, the economies have performed well in recent years, however, collectively reaching an average rate of growth of about 5% per annum between 1980 and 1990, slowing down to about 2% per annum during the early 1990s. The combined 1993 Gross Domestic Product (GNP) for all of the islands was estimated at US$1.3 billion with the service industry accounting for over 60%, and the tourist industry contributing heavily to that sector. The industrial and agricultural sectors together account for the remainder, with industry accounting for a slightly higher contribution to GDP.

 B. Environmental Linkages to Economic Development 1.5 Although the environmental problems are not overwhelming in the OECS countries, the linkages between development and the environment are nowhere more evident than in these countries. The inter-related problems of population pressure and land scarcity have led to an over-exploitation of natural resources. Forests have been relentlessly cultivated for subsistence, commercial agriculture and logging, while the islands' skewed land ownership and complex land tenure arrangements have given rise to over-utilization of marginal lands. The consequences have been accelerated soil erosion, land slides, increased flooding during rainy periods, reduced water supplies during dry periods, deterioration in water quality, sedimentation of rivers and coastal areas, and consequent threat to mangroves, sea-grass beds and coral reefs. Concurrently, increasing levels of domestic consumption, coupled with additional numbers of tourists and cruise ship passengers, are responsible for generating increasing quantities of solid and liquid waste. The inadequate existing facilities for the collection, treatment and disposal of these wastes means that much of it ends up in informal dumps, watercourses or the sea. 1.6 To safeguard public health, the quality of their environment and thus protecting their tourism base in particular, the countries are increasingly interested in undertaking policies and programs to protect the environment. These concerns focus on: (a) improvement in waste management; (b) attention to land overuse, including deforestation; (c) reversal of coastal degradation; and (d) attention to water pollution. 1.7 The current state of natural resource degradation, particularly of coastal and marine resources, poses a serious threat to the sustainability of local economies which are largely dependent on tourism and fishing, in addition to agriculture. To address these issues, the governments are committed to: (a) change economic policies so as to provide incentives to encourage conservation, (b) introduce cost recovery for environmental protection and user fees for national parks, (c) divest public lands and introduce land titling, (d) increase public awareness through education, (e) improve the legal and regulatory framework, (f) strengthen environmental monitoring and enforcement mechanisms, and (g) invest in waste disposal facilities. II. SECTORAL PERSPECTIVE A. The Port Sector 2.1 There are a total of 10 main ports in the OECS countries, with another 29 secondary ports which are made up mostly of small craft harbors, small fishing ports and major yacht anchorages. There is little information on the annual traffic of these ports, with most of the cargo being break-bulk, mainly agricultural goods for export, with some container activity. Table 2.1 indicates the location of the main ports and small crafts harbors.

This traffic is particularly important as it directly impacts on the tourist industry which in most of the countries is the main economic growth sector. Table 2.2 presents stayover tourist and ship passenger traffic by country. Most cruise-ship traffic originates from the US and is composed of passengers travelling both on holiday cruise liners (89%), and on private yachts (9%). The balance of 2% arrives by cargo vessel (Paras.6.3 and Table 6.1 in Section 6). While many islands have seen a major increase in tourist arrivals overall, the biggest increases have occurred in the cruise ship industry, where passenger arrivals have substantially increased in the period 1986-92. Stayover tourist arrivals have also increased, but not as dramatically. The result is: (a) port congestion, where the ports of St. John's in Antigua, Castries in St. Lucia, and St. George's in Grenada frequently have as many as 6 cruise ships in port at any one time, either alongside dedicated cruise ship berths or general cargo berths, or lying at anchor in the harbor; and (b) an associated increase in tourist and passenger generated waste, either in the islands or on the way to the islands.

Environmental Issues associated with Domestic and Ship Waste Disposal Facilities 2.3 Among all of the environmental issues facing the OECS countries, addressing the related issues of ineffective liquid and solid waste management and coastal and marine resource degradation, are of top priority. These problems pose a threat to public health, the environmental quality of the islands, and to the future of the islands' principal income and employment generating activity; i.e. tourism. Solid waste management conditions and practices in each of the countries are similar in many ways, with some of the main similarities comprising the following: in all countries, except Antigua, a significant proportion of the population is not served by any type of waste collection system; there is little public understanding of the public health, environmental, tourism or economic implications of inadequate waste management systems; the capacity of all countries to improve waste management systems is severely constrained by the existing institutional framework, most particularly at the technical and financial level; existing infrastructure in all countries is under-capitalized and poorly maintained and operated;
 - 7 - controls on the management of international wastes entering the countries are either non-existent or totally ineffective; 2.4 There are a number of types of solid waste generated in each of the OECS countries. The major types of waste are: (a) residential waste generation, estimated at about 0.58 kg/person/day in urban areas and 0.52 kg/person/day outside major urban and economic centers; (b) industrial, commercial and institutional waste generation, estimated at the equivalent of about 0.45 kg/person/day in urban areas and 0.27 kg/person/day outside of major urban and economic centers; (c) stayover tourist solid waste, estimated to be double residential waste generation on a per capita basis, and equal to about 1.16 kg/tourist population equivalent/day; (d) ship-generated waste, with estimates varying widely depending not only on the number of passengers but also on the type of vessel and length of the voyage, but estimated at 2.95 kg/person/day for cruise-ships, 2.3 kg/person/day on merchant vessels and 1.6 kg/person/day on yachts; and (f) special wastes, such as hospital wastes generated in small amounts but which require special handling. 2.5 For domestically-generated waste, collection systems vary widely in their coverage and efficiency but are inadequate in all countries. In most cases a combination of curb-side and communal skip collection is provided at frequencies varying from daily to weekly. System coverage varies from an estimated 85 % in Antigua to less than 50% in Dominica and Grenada where many areas remain unserved. The other OECS countries manage a collection efficiency of about 60-70%. The main problems facing all countries in achieving efficient and environmentally appropriate disposal of solid waste include: (a) lack of capacity at existing landfill sites; (b) poor sanitary conditions at landfill sites; (c) indiscriminate burning of waste at these sites; (d) visual and odor problems; (e) pollution of ground and surface waters through leachate migration; (f) poor accessibility and management of sites; (g) indiscriminate on-site dumping; and (h) inadequate and poorly operated and maintained compaction and other landfill equipment. 2.6 In addition to solid wastes generated on the islands, waste discharges from ships and yachts add significantly to the problems. While some countries refuse to receive solid waste from ships, in all cases some ship-generated waste is already being deposited, with or without the knowledge of the government. It is the ship's agents who generally hire private haulage contractors to carry out this activity for large vessels. For yachts, private individuals frequently offer to remove solid wastes which is then disposed of indiscriminately elsewhere on the coastline. While port authorities are mandated to take temporary custody of cargoes in transit if ships are found to be in violation of the MARPOL 73/78 Convention (Annex V) this is never carried out, nor do the governments have the facilities to do so. Presently, these same port authorities are not directly involved in ship-generated waste disposal or treatment since none of the ports have solid waste reception or treatment facilities on their premises, and they have no capability to deal directly with these wastes.

Based on information which is available, calculations show volumes of ship-generated waste which could be landed at between about four and 18 percent of domestic waste generation in the countries. This excludes food waste, which under the MARPOL convention can be ground up and disposed of at sea beyond certain limits and under particular conditions. C. The MARPOL Convention 2.7 The MARPOL 73/78 Convention currently has five Annexes, one of which (Annex V) provides a regulatory framework for the prevention of pollution of international waters by solid waste from ships. This Annex became effective on December 31, 1988. 2.8 In 1991, at the Marine Environment protection Committee Meeting in London (MEPC 31), a proposal to adopt the Wider Caribbean as a Special Area under Annex V was approved. The 37 territories and 28 states which make up the Wider Caribbean were asked to endeavor to provide adequate acceptable reception facilities for Annex V wastes at all ports and harbors receiving international shipping. The rationale for declaring the Wider Caribbean as a Special Area for just Annex V of MARPOL 73/78 stemmed from the fact that pollution from marine garbage, largely emanating from cruise ships, was considered to be of the highest priority. Furthermnore, since a significant proportion of marine debris is contributed by land-based sources, the ship- generated solid waste initiative was seen to be an opportunity for these countries to concurrently address the problems of both shore-based and ship-generated waste. 2.9 The regulations governing provision of reception facilities within Special Areas state that Governments must undertake to provide adequate reception facilities for solid waste at all ports within a special area, taking into account the special needs of ships operating in such areas. 2.10 In addition to MARPOL 73/78 Annex V waste, Annex I (which deals with oily waste), and Annex II (which deals with chemical waste) are also mandatory under the provisions of MARPOL 73/78. However, these wastes impact upon few ports in the region. Annex A attached hereto provides a more detailed explanation of the history and implications of MARPOL 73/78, and the Special Area designation of the Wider Caribbean.

The Legislative and Institutional Framework and the OECS Secretariat 2.11 Within the OECS Secretariat there are two units which concern themselves with environmental issues; the Natural Resources Management Unit (NRMU) and the Legal Unit (LU). Outside of the Secretariat there is also the Caribbean Environmental Health Institute (CEHI) which has a Caribbean wide remit in the sector. 2.12 The NRMU was formed in 1986 with a mandate to: coordinate regional environmental programs and activities on behalf of the OECS Secretariat; provide technical assistance and support to the OECS member countries; and promote cooperation among OECS countries in environmental management. Although its role does not include direct project management, the NRMU has been used as a focus for project management units, and has been involved in the successful implementation of two major donor funded programs: a GTZ financed cooperation program in natural resource management; and the USAID funded Environment and Coastal Resource (ENCORE) Project. It has also been involved in other projects with UNDP and other agencies, and with the project preparation phase for this project - the OECS Solid Waste Management Project. The Unit is guided by a Technical Advisory Committee of senior environmentalists and planners from the OECS member states. NRMU with GTZ support, is able to provide advice to member countries on an ad hoc basis, including issues concerning solid waste management. The LU is involved in a number of matters relating to the development and harmonization of legislation, and provides legal services and advice to the OECS member states. The Unit reports to the OECS Legal Affairs Committee, comprised of the OECS Attorneys-General. The LU maintains close contact with the OECS countries' Foreign Affairs Committees which would be responsible for MARPOL 73/78 implementation. Both the NRMU and LU report directly to the OECS Authority. 2.13 The CEHI, which was established in 1981, deals primarily with the coastal marine environment, and particularly monitoring standards, in CARICOM member countries. It has been involved in a series of technical assistance packages to the OECS countries on matters relating to solid waste management. 2.14 Within the OECS countries themselves, responsibility for environmental management in general and waste management in particular is distributed among a number of agencies. These agencies are characterized by uneven technical and managerial capabilities and poor coordination. In all countries the ultimate responsibility for solid waste collection, treatment and disposal falls under the Ministries of Health. However, at the executive level, responsibilities are frequently shared by other ministries (Ministry of Works and Communications), and/or local governments. At the local level, these authorities are uniformnly technically and managerially weak.
 - 10- 2.15 In the case of ship-generated waste, while port authorities are responsible for port operations, waste management is invariably handled by private contractors hired by the ship's agents. As a result, waste landed is often taken from the port and dumped either at solid waste disposal sites or elsewhere without any monitoring or supervision by government authorities. 2.16 Legislation relating to solid waste management is patchy and there is little in the way of waste management policy. In a number of countries legislation is in place, but enforcement is weak. (Annexes B-G include descriptions of the legislative environment in each country). The main institutional constraints to improved waste management may be summarized as follows: (a) limited absorptive capacity of existing institutions; (b) lack of financial control and accountability; (c) inadequate or ineffective legislative instruments; (d) technical and managerial weakness; and (e) inefficient and poorly defined administrative responsibilities. 2.17 It is apparent that the OECS countries face numerous challenges in the implementation of a solid waste management strategy. Some of the more problematic include: Historically, the OECS countries have tended to approach waste management problems and solutions separately, with little communication or interaction among themselves. Systems have therefore developed to best suit individual characteristics of each country with little regard to the potential benefits of a more regional approach, which could inter alia share resources and expertise in resolving waste management and other environmental problems. Awareness of waste management issues and waste diversion opportunities is rather poor in the majority of these countries. In general, domestic waste management is considered entirely the responsibility of government, not of the individual. Furthermore, industry waste generation is rarely considered part of the production process and cost, and consequently, is treated as an externality. The OECS countries have small populations that tend to be concentrated in a number of urban areas that are disbursed throughout each country - frequently around the coasts. Collectively they are situated at considerable distances from international markets, which makes it particularly difficult to develop recycling options, not only because of access and transportation problems, but also as a result of poor awareness of waste diversion needs and opportunities.

Rationale for the Bank's Involvement 3.1 The rationale for Bank involvement in the proposed project concerns its role as catalyst in bringing together the six OECS countries to jointly address one of the most urgent environmental problems facing them, that is the contamination of their terrestrial environments and pollution of their coastal zones and the Caribbean Sea. The Bank is working closely with the OECS governments, regional agencies and other international agencies to assist the OECS countries in developing a coordinated regional environmental strategy supported by action plans at both the regional and national levels. To this end, the Bank has been successful in mobilizing incremental funding for this operation through the Global Environmental Facility (GEF), Caribbean Development Bank (CDB), the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Union (EU). Project Objectives 3.2 The proposed project is to be the first in a series of environmentally-oriented activities which will ensure the future maintenance of environmental quality in the OECS countries. The objective of this operation is to reduce public health risks and protect the environmental integrity of the islands and their coastal and marine systems, by improving domestic solid waste management facilities and facilitating compliance with the "Special Area" designation of the Caribbean Sea for MARPOL 73/78 Annex V wastes. The Project will reduce terrestrial and marine pollution in this area through avoiding and discouraging indiscriminate disposal of solid waste both on and off shore. A further objective is to significantly enhance public health and environmental quality by strengthening the countries' capacities to effectively manage and dispose of solid waste in an environmentally sustainable manner. More specifically, project objectives are to assist the OECS governments to: (a) improve the coverage and effectiveness of domestic solid waste collection and disposal facilities; (b) reduce pollution of international and territorial waters caused by ship-generated solid wastes; (c) improve the collection, treatment and disposal of ship-generated solid wastes; (d) assist the beneficiary countries in the establishment of appropriate legal and institutional frameworks to enable effective management and disposal of shore and ship-generated waste; (e) assist in the preparation of plans and programs to address the problems of collection, treatment and disposal of liquid wastes; and (f) identify Regional opportunities for reduction, recovery and recycling of solid waste. 3.3 The above objectives, which focus on increasing the level of environmental protection and improving environmental conditions, will be achieved by:
 - 13 - (a) institutional strengthening and improved policy, regulatory and incentive frameworks to manage solid waste; (b) addressing critical deficiencies in the domestic solid waste collection, treatment and disposal sectors; (c) provision of suitable reception, collection, handling, treatment and disposal facilities for ship-generated waste; (d) enhancing the opportunities for waste recovery and recycling; (e) encouraging improved cost recovery for solid waste management services; (f) establishing a regional policy and institutional framework for fostering collaboration among the OECS islands inter alia on cost recovery for disposal of ship-generated waste; (g) providing technical assistance for liquid waste collection, treatment and disposal systems in the OECS countries; and (h) encourage greater coordination between the OECS countries and donor cormmunity in the provision of environmental assistance. 3.4 It is envisaged that the regional framework adopted in establishing the project, and the regional component proposed as part of the project, will encourage greater coordination between the OECS countries and donor community in the provision of enviromnental assistance. The regional approach is particularly important in view of the commonality of many of the problems and issues faced by the OECS countries. This approach should assist in the development of strategies required to mitigate further environmental problems in the future. C. Project Description 3.5 The proposed project comprises a number of national components, which are similar for each of the OECS countries, and a regional component which covers issues common to all. National Components 3.6 The National Components comprise the following three major elements:
 - 14 - (a) The introduction of solid waste management improvements and investments in each of the six countries the purpose of which will be to address the major deficiencies in the sector by financing improvements to the existing solid waste storage; collection; and disposal systems through the purchase of collection and other equipment and the development of appropriate disposal facilities. (b) Investments in port reception facilities in all six countries to address the problem of ship-generated solid (MARPOL 73/78 Annex V) waste which is currently dumped in coastal zones and international waters around the OECS countries. It will include the provision of convenient receptacles at all ports, harbors, marinas and major anchorages, and where necessary specialized equipment (eg. barges) to facilitate the off-loading of the ship-generated solid waste; the equipment necessary to treat this waste at the port or the point of final disposal; and, the equipment necessary to transport the waste to the ultimate disposal site. (c) The rationalization of the existing institutional framework in all six countries through the creation and development of solid waste management entities to improve management and control of solid waste and improve cost recovery mechanisms for the services provided. 3.7 The basic composition of activities in this category will include the rationalization of existing collection and disposal facilities and conversion of existing dumps into sanitary landfill sites or development of new sanitary landfill sites; provision of facilities for the treatment of medical and other hazardous wastes; and the introduction of measures to encourage recovery of recyclable items from solid waste, including the setting up of "buy-back" depots and development of a set of incentives to help achieve this recycling objective. Specifically, the project components include: (a) provision of storage facilities (bins, dumpsters or skips) to augment the existing system for storage of domestically generated waste, particularly where curb-side collection systems are operated; (b) procurement of collection and transportation equipment to augment the existing systems for the collection of solid waste and its transportation to the point of ultimate disposal; (c) provision of collection and storage facilities for the reception of ship- generated wastes at large ports, small craft harbors and anchorages from cruise ships, cargo vessels and small crafts including yachts; and procurement of equipment to facilitate transport of this waste to the site of final disposal, or to a point where the waste can be collected for eventual disposal (including barges);
 - 15 - (d) provision of equipment to support efforts at extending opportunities for waste recovery and recycling (including processing of recyclable materials and composting); (e) construction of transfer stations for solid waste (in two countries only - Grenada and Dominica only), and the procurement of transfer equipment; (f) development of new sanitary landfill sites for the disposal of solid waste or the upgrading of existing dump sites to sanitary landfill facilities and the closure, redemption and reclamation of unsuitable and inappropriate existing dump sites; (g) procurement of compaction and other operational equipment necessary to assist in the correct management of solid waste at the new sanitary landfill sites, and to increase landfill lifetime and maintain site operation in a satisfactory condition; (h) procurement of equipment for the effective treatment of hospital wastes (in three countries only - Antigua and Barbuda, St. Lucia, St. Kitts and Nevis only); (i) procurement of equipment to assist in the monitoring and operation of the improved solid waste management system; and (j) assistance with the establishment of a sanctuary for the threatened Grenada Dove (using GET funds in Grenada only). Growing international concern for protection of the environment generally, including the marine environment in particular, led to the convening of the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment in 1972 which drew attention, amongst other things, to the need to protect the oceans from vessel-source pollution. A series of tanker casualties, the increasing amount of wastes dumped in the ocean and chronic pollution of beaches and coastal waters had drawn global attention to this problem. 2. The international community's response to the above concerns was the adoption, under the auspices of the International Maritime Organization (IMO) of the Intemational Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (1973) and a Protocol to that Convention (1978), together normally referred to as MARPOL 73/78 with the aim of reducing and, if required, eliminating the long-standing practice of discharging wastes from ships into the marine environment. 3. iMARPOL 73/78 requires both that ships retain their wastes on board, discharging them only at their port of call, and that ports provide adequate reception facilities to receive these wastes. 4. Different types of substances or cargo carried by ships are addressed in the five annexes of MARPOL 73/78 as follows: Annex I, oil; Annex II, noxious liquid substances in bulk; Annex III, harmful substances in packaged forms; Annex IV, sewage; and Annex V, garbage. 5. Ratification of MARPOL 73/78 by a State does not necessarily have to include all annexes. Annexes III,IV and V are referred to as optional Annexes that need not be accepted by a State when it ratifies or accedes to MARPOL 73/78. However, the optional Annexes cannot be ratified separately; these can only be ratified in combination with or after ratification of Annexes I and II of MARPOL 73/78.
 - 2 - 6. MARPOL 73/78 and its Annexes provide specific discharge standards for different substances. For some substances (e.g. plastics in Annex V) MARPOL 73/78 introduces a complete ban on their discharge. It also provides for the option of designating specific sea areas as "special areas" under Annex I and II or V (or under a combination of these Annexes). Stricter discharge regulations apply to these special areas. 7. Following an IMO/UNEP sponsored workshop in Caracas, October 1990, and also the 30th session of the Marine Environment Protection Committee (MEPC) of the IMO, November 1990, several Governments in the Wider Caribbean Region (WCR) sought from the MEPC a "Special Area" designation for the WCR's sea area under Annex V of MARPOL 73/78. Under this arrangement, ships are prohibited from discharging garbage at sea within the Gulf of Mexico and the WCR. A proposal was presented to MEPC's 31st session where it was formallv adopted on July 4, 1991 (MEPC Res. 48(31)). The amendment entered into force on 4 April 1993. 8. The States and Territories of the WCR were invited to examine in detail the implications of the "Special Area" designation and to endeavor to provide adequate and acceptable reception facilities for Annex V wastes throughout the region. The "Special Area" designation for the WCR will only become effective one year after the required reception facilities are established and made operational in the ports of the region. 9. The provision of reception facilities is a major instrument in MARPOL 73/78's efforts to reduce or end the discharge of ship-generated wastes into the marine environment. Annexes I, II and V contain regulations with regard to reception facilities that must be provided in ports, respectively for oily wastes, noxious liquid substances, and garbage. MARPOL 73/78's effectiveness in combating marine pollution from ships is as much determined by the effectiveness of its regulations regarding the provision of reception facilities as it is by the effectiveness of implementation and enforcement of its requirements concerning port inspection and reporting. 10. There are, however, other important elements that determine the effectiveness of MARPOL 73/78 worldwide and also in the WCR and more specifically, in the States and Territories of the WCR. These dictate that: the relevant national primary and secondary maritime legislation has to be in place and up to date and many of the important IMO Conventions other than MARPOL 73/78 are also ratified and implemented by adoption of national legislation; MARPOL 73/78, including its optional Annexes (in particular Annex V) be ratified;
 - 3- MARPOL 73/78's provisions are implemented by adoption of appropriate national legislation and that there exists an effective institutional framework both for the legislative process for drafting and adoption of the necessary laws and an effective maritime administration for the overview, implementation and enforcement thereof; MARPOL 73/78's provisions are actively enforced by the States and Territories in the WCR to ensure full compliance with its regulations; other relevant international instruments (e.g. the Cartagena Convention, the London Convention, the Vina del Mar Agreement, and the Basel Convention) should also be ratified and implemented; and reception facilities for ship-generated wastes be provided, the institutional arrangements for effective operation of these facilities be in place, and strategies and infrastructure for the effective management (e.g. treatment, disposal) of these wastes be developed. 11. In others, general enabling and primary maritime legislation may be in place, but the necessary regulations and other measures necessary to give the enabling legislation practical effect have either not been developed or may not be up to date or effective. Some progress has been made in some countries in this area in respect of enactment of shipping legislation or updating outdated legislation, or both, as a result of, among other developments, bi-lateral projects, the appointment of a Regional Maritime Safety Advisor for the Caribbean by the IMO, and the appointment of a Regional Consultant on Marine Pollution, Port Safety and Security for the Wider Caribbean. Another important initiative is the LEGISMAR project in five Central American States established under UN auspices with the IMO as executing agency to promote adoption and implementation of comprehensive maritime legislation. Current Legislative and Policy Conditions 1 . The following legislative and policy framework is in place in Dominica: A Litter Act was passed in 1990, to "make provision for the abatement of nuisances caused by the littering of premises and public places and for purposes connected therewith or incidental thereto" .' Its provisions allow for the fining and/or incarcerating of persons littering in public places or on private property. Responsibility for enforcement is given to the police who may issue a ticket. In addition, under the Act, derelict vehicles must be removed, subject to notice by the Minister of Health. However, the Act remains largely un-enforced. "No up-to-date standards or specifications have been established for the construction and operation of solid waste dumps whose leachate may contaminate surface and underground waters."2 The National Parks and Protected Areas Act (1975) gives authority to a National Parks Advisory Council to, among others, "preserve their [protected areas] natural beauty... "I This act also lacks enforcement. The National Development Corporation Act (1988) enables the Minister to empower the Corporation to make and enforce regulations that promote Dominica as a tourism destination. It is noted by the Caribbean Law Institute that, if overseen by the Minister in charge of national parks, forestry, beach control, fisheries, etc., such a vehicle could be used to enforce environmental concerns and legislation related to tourism. Current Legislative and Policy Conditions 1 . The following waste management legislative and policy conditions prevail in St. Vincent and the Grenadines: As with the other countries in the region, St. Vincent and the Grenadines has a number of laws that are relevant to environmental protection, although most are outdated and inappropriate. The Public Health Act (1977) enables the government to deal with solid and liquid wastes, including the issuing of statutory notices to abate nuisances and the prosecution of offenses. "Since no regulations have been made to guide inspectors in their enforcement duties, reliance has to be placed on the substantive provisions of the Act to ensure compliance with its provisions, which are deficient in terms of specificity, thereby compromising the effectiveness of the enforcement process"'. In 1991, a new Litter Act was passed, allowing for fines and jail terms to be imposed on offenders. However, overall, solid waste management is suffering from an absence of clearly stated national goals and objectives, whereby effective planning and management is not possible2. St. Vincent and the Grenadines does not have in place any national land use plans. The country is in the initial stages of developing Spatial/Land Use Plans, funded through UNDP. An Environmental Action Plan is in the preparation process with the assistance of the World Bank. The Town and Country Planning Act (1976) enables the government to take action on the development of illegal structures in the country. Physical Planning Department representatives noted that from a planning Enviroranental Laws of the Commonwealth Canbbean", p.313. 2 lbid, p. 315.

To find a suitable location that is removed from human settlements, not near other incompatible land uses, such as agricultural areas, water courses, etc., and accessible by vehicles, is not easy given the geography and developmental history of the country. An integrated planning approach is required to resolve these issues and identify a site that is suitable over the long term, and to protect it from encroachment by other uses at a later date. Environmental matters are primarily dealt with in the Ministry of Education and Health, although no specific legislation exists to guide environmental management activities and there is no division, or complement of staff, to deal with this sector. Waste Disposal Facilities 3. Six waste disposal facilities serve the major population on St. Vincent and the Grenadines: Amos Vale (serving Kingstown and region), Chili (serving the Georgetown area), Wallilabou (serving the Barrouallie area), Fitz-Hughes (serving the Chateaubelair area), Raintree (serving Bequia Island) and Clifton (serving Union Island). Each of these facilities is known to be underlain by sandy soils, except Raintree and Clifton, which have a clay/sand soil base. No controls are in place to manage leachate or landfill gas at any of the sites. It is likely that leachate is entering surface water adjacent to the Chili facility; this water is used by residents for washing. Similarly, it is considered likelv that leachate from the Barrouallie and Raintree sites is entering streams adjacent to these facilities. The base of the Amos Vale site is at sea level and close to the shore line, which is likely to result in the rapid migration of leachate into the marine environment. doc.repnme: Antigua & Barbuda, Commonwealth of Dominica, Grenada, St. Kitts & Nevis, St. Lucia, St. Vincent & the Grenadines - Solid Waste Management Project
doc.abstracts: TThe Solid Waste Management Project is to be the first in a series of environmentally-oriented activities which will ensure the future maintenance of environmental quality in the Organization of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS) countries. The objective of this operation is to reduce public health risks and protect the environmental integrity of the island and their costal and marine systems, by improving domestic solid waste management facilities and facilitating compliance with the "Special Area" designation of the Caribbean Sea. The project will reduce terrestrial and marine pollution in this area through avoiding and discouraging indiscriminate disposal of solid waste both on and off shore. A further objective is to significantly enhance public health and environmental quality by strengthening the countries' capacities to effectively manage and dispose of solid waste in an environmentally sustainable manner. More specifically, project objectives are to assist the OECS governments to: (a) improve the coverage and effectiveness of domestic solid waste collection and disposal facilities; (b) reduce pollution of international and territorial waters caused by ship-generated solid waste; (c) improve the collection, treatment and disposal of ship-generated solid wastes; (d) assist the beneficiary countries in the establishment of appropriate legal and institutional frameworks to enable effective management and disposal of shore and ship-generated waste; (e) assist in the preparation of plans and programs to address the problems of collection, treatment and disposal of liquid waste; and (f) identify Regional opportunities for reduction, recovery and recycling of solid waste.
